qas.question: What was the first great English translation?
When was the Wycliffe Bible translated?
When did the age of great English prose translation begin?
What adaptation of Arthurian romances took so many liberties with the source material that it could hardly be called a translation?
The Tyndale New Testament was one of the first great translations from what style?
What was the last great German translation?
When was the Wycliffe Bible burned?
When did the age of great English prose translation stop?
What adaptation of Arthurian romances took no liberties with the source material?

context: The first great English translation was the <a0_0><b5_0>Wycliffe Bible<b5_0/><a0_0/> (ca. <a1_0><b6_0>1382<b6_0/><a1_0/>), which showed the weaknesses of an underdeveloped English prose. Only at the <a2_0><b7_0>end of the 15th century<b7_0/><a2_0/> did the great age of English prose translation begin with Thomas Malory's <a3_0><b8_0>Le Morte Darthur<b8_0/><a3_0/>—an adaptation of Arthurian romances so free that it can, in fact, hardly be called a true translation. The first great <a4_0>Tudor<a4_0/> translations are, accordingly, the Tyndale New Testament (1525), which influenced the Authorized Version (1611), and Lord Berners' version of Jean Froissart's Chronicles (1523–25).
